Comment: I think this is true to some degree. If you look at Bill Clinton and Obama, they gave their audience a feeling of hope. Trump actually does too since most Trump supporters say that he gives them a sense of hope, while far less Kamala voters said the same about her.      Bill Clinton and Obama both knew what the people's biggest concerns were: the economy, the deficit, inflation, and unemployment. They both made people feel like they understood their problems, and then they convinced people that they knew how to turn it around. Bill Clinton was a master at convincing people he knew what to do, and that his policies were proven to work. He made everything he did sound like common sense. He also wasn't afraid to call out Bush, and made him look like he was a do-nothing president.   But he constantly gave off a sense of optimism, and assured people to vote for him to create prosperity like they hadn't seen in a long time.      Obama was also good at convincing people that he knew how to fix our problems, but kind of differently than Bill. He said he'd create jobs, fix our healthcare system, switch back to American oil, and not take money from lobbies or secret actors. He made people believe he'd actually listen to and work for them. Where Obama was better than anybody so far is **ground game**. He had way more volunteers on the ground going door to door, visiting colleges, and posted on street corners. They handed out "Hope" and "Yes We Can" stickers and buttons all over college campuses. This is part of how he won the younger crowd. He also had his own version of a Snopes page to combat lies, which would have been crucial for Biden and Harris.      If Democrats want the White House back, they need somebody who makes people feel hopeful, and like they care about their struggles, while Vance or whoever doesn't even pretend to. They need a better ground game than Biden and Harris had, and they could borrow a couple ideas from Obama. Their campaign should look more grass roots, and have a wide network of volunteers. Talk to the elderly about what they want to hear about, and talk to young people about what they want to hear about. Young people aren't as concerned about Social Security or Medicare, and the elderly aren't as concerned about abortion or free college tuition/trade school.
Author: x_xHaunter313

Comment: I‚Äôm a Dem millennial male but the party has got to reach out to this group. Better or worse it‚Äôs the electorate you have. We can‚Äôt change 2024 now. Have to focus on the future.¬†

Comment: No they didn't. Polling showed Trump had a strong hold on Gen Z males, and his campaign was pretty open about the fact that young men was one of the key demos they were targeting. In fact, there were jokes all over Reddit about how they be skipping the vote to play the Call of Duty game that was being released that day and hedging your bets on young men is a losing strategy given how they routinely rank at the top of low-frequency voters.  Even then, I think Trump actually underperformed with that age group compared to what the polling was predicting.  I have no idea where you're getting these "old polls" from. But, I mean, the thing about polling is that it's not static. The young men who voted against Trump in 2020 are not the young men who voted against him in 2024 because of the whole aging thing.

Comment: I mean I get it. I'm a left leaning, NYT reading, higher income, college educated, Bostonian millennial man embedded in a social circle of liberal educators and LGBTQ folk whom I love.   And even I started to feel ostracized/isolated in the grips of Me Too and BLM. It was never that I disagreed with the movements. But boy I still felt like the enemy and like I didn't have a place. Speaking up was speaking over and hanging back was not supporting and the only way to fit the narrative was to demonize my advantage and minimize my agency in my accomplishments.   I get it, that's only a taste of what others grew up going through. I'm not looking for sympathy. I'm just saying that even for me, it felt not good.    For a lost, uncertain young man. Especially one struggling to achieve what their parents and older siblings did, I see why they were turned off. And when right wing media came in to coddle them and tell them they were special and being oppressed, I'm not surprised it worked.

Comment: To be a little fair, boomers held Jim Crow and other racist tendencies based on where they grew up. Unlike younger maga, unless they grew out of it, they are set in their ways. For example, my former best friend from high school didn't have a good relationship with his father, even though his father was around. Because he hated learning as his father was strict about schoolwork, he didn't care for it after being stationed in the Midwest and was persuaded by conservative Christianity. His father had the best intentions but was super stubborn. His father was slightly conservative, although I didn't know to what extent. My friend was looking for that father figure that nurtured him, and accidentally found it in what is now MAGA. Hence why MAGA goes after young men because a lot of them today are raised by single parent households, mostly by mothers with no father figure. As someone who was raised by one, I can tell you I nearly fell down that hole, but was fortunate enough to have someone else step into a fatherly figure to help avoid falling into MAGA.   Don't underestimate them exploring this. Even in two parent households, if the father isn't paying attention to the boy and instead repeats the ways of the past, we'll keep getting maga.  Just my .02
